text:
I think you should just open issues on packages that do that.
This is a very solvable problem.

Since presumably they wanted docs but forgot to test them.
The default autodocs that just show all the docstrings are worth having.

Hiding the links seems like hiding the problem rather than fixing it.

text: It looks like I’m in the minority here, but I actually really prefer (good) docs to READMEs. Sometimes I need a quick example, sometimes a deep tutorial, and other time I’m looking for something very specific. Well organized docs keep me from having to scroll through a bunch of stuff I don’t want to see at the moment.

text:
>  Adding docs and doc links should be a conscious decision, not something that just happens as the result of creating a package
Yes, in the case of PkgTemplates.jl:
• the default template returned by  `Template()` does not include Documenter docs (nor corresponding badge)
• only if you include the `Documenter` plugin in your Template (which is not the default) will you get docs and a corresponding badge (i.e. you only get the badge if you have the docs -- and even then you can turn off having the badge -- you can't get the badge without having the docs)

text: Publish.jl is pretty nice for this. It uses the README.md as the main page of the docs by default IIRC. So for small packages, the README can be code examples that also run when viewed via the actual docs. On top of that you can add a `toc.md` which takes like five seconds to fill out, and all your docstrings are generated into a nice filterable table in the docs.
